review_title: For being a multi-million dollar company, their health benefits leave a lot to be desired
pros:
Lots of opportunities for transfers to other departments or other plants

Very generous life insurance plans

For the most part all team members do their best to support each other, at least at the corporate office

cons:
Health insurance deductibles and out of pocket maximums are ridiculously high

The executive leadership utilizes a very "top down" approach to decision making. Rarely are lower level team members consulted on major operational changes. If they are consulted, recommendations or suggestions are usually ignored

Managers are often overloaded with responsibilities. This causes the manager's relationship with their direct reports to suffer because the manager may not have time to fully devote to the issues their direct reports are facing because they are being overloaded with responsibilities for a completely different area

There is also a worrying trend of positions being eliminated and responsibilities being added to the remaining employees with little to no extra pay as part of a "lean" model business strategy
Advice to Management
When it comes to benefits, it seems Tyson takes a quantity over quality approach. Yes, all the specialized accident and disability plans are nice, but any benefit from those plans is negated when you have to pay an $1,100 deductible and $5,000 out of pocket maximum on your health insurance plan. Focus on bringing down the cost of the health insurance instead of wasting so much effort pushing those superfluous disability and accident plans. 

Do not overload your managers with responsibilities for conflicting areas. Allow managers to focus their attention on one area. Along those same lines, in the era of COVID, a lean business strategy will just no longer support necessary operations. You must invest in creating new positions instead of just trying to hoist additional work and responsibilities on fewer team members.

Throughout my time at Tyson Foods I received excellent feedback from leadership and everyone I worked with. After months of making great accomplishments and progress, meeting deadlines, etc. my manager began to acting negatively toward me, communicating less with me as my time ended abruptly. One day, out of nowhere, I was invited to a meeting titled, "Action Plan," and it only included me, my manager and a team member from HR. At the time, I didn't think anything of it, until the meeting began. My manager began speaking allowed and stating that I was being put under a 30 day Action Plan due to "lack of collaboration." My reaction was a huge surprise, because up until that point, I was told I was doing everything great! My manager then assigned me to create a Brainshark video over the 5C's (which I completed) and told to put together a proposal for leadership (which I spent days working on and gathering information and also completed). After receiving positive feedback from my manager about how great I was doing, I had not heard anything else. 

Fast forward, Tyson lays 500 employees off, thankfully I was unaffected, or so I thought. Then the COVID-19 pandemic sends the entire company working remote. One day, at random, I get a Zoom meeting invite from my manager and HR. As I feel fully confident going into this meeting that everything was going great and we were going to drop the Action Plan. My manager begins by stating that this will be my last day with Tyson and I am being terminated, I am in total disbelief (so is every single person I work with). I tried asking my manager why this was happening or what the reason was, he immediately LEFT the call without saying anything (real 5C material if you ask me). I tried asking HR the same question and why my manager left the call. She said, “well, we decided that we were going to go with performance issues as the reason,” without any details or reasoning. 

Short story, my manager took my proposal, never even looked or commented on my Brainshark video (which I now realize was just busy work), fired me for no real reason and didn’t even have the courage to stay on the call.
I would consider taking the position back if I didn’t have to work for the same manager. Especially considering we are in the middle of a pandemic, my entire family is sick and my insurance was cut off on the day of my termination. My manager knew I had a family, he knew many of my family members were sick. The chances of securing a job during this time are little to none.
Advice to Management
Treat your employees with candor and care (and actually follow through).

Investigate whether these situations are actually true or false! I was a valued employee and loved the work I was able to do during my time there, only getting excellent feedback. I even stated to a team member that I could see myself retiring at Tyson. 

I truly hope the sincerity of my message is heard.

pros: Tyson as an overall company can be a good company to work for. But it depends on what location you get. I've heard many good things about many of their other locations.
cons:
I was hired fresh out of college, as a processing plant supervisor. This is a position that they normally full by promoting from within the plant (ie promoting leads to supervisors) but for some reason they decided to hire a few people out of college. They provided almost no training or support for me, and I struggled greatly to learn the ropes as someone who has never worked inside a processing plant before. They had a sink or swim mentality when it came to "training" me for the job, which they promised they would do at my interview.

Work/life balance was awful for the salary I was getting, I regularly worked 60-hour weeks as well as several 70-hour weeks. High stress environment, had to deal with issues from everyone: workers, coworkers, bosses, USDA, safety, maintenance, etc.

The lack of support from upper management was the straw that broke the camel's back. Some of my employees held grudges against me because they didn't like the fact that I was 20+ years their junior and a woman of color, was their supervisor. These employees went to HR to say that I acted better than them because I had a college degree...when in fact, I was just doing my job as their supervisor and wrote them up for their bad behavior on the job. Upper management wrote a warning against me, didn't let me defend myself or listen to my side of the story, etc. 

Beware working at a union plant. The union will shield its members from ALL attempted write-ups for bad behavior, missed work, etc. and have them thrown out the window. Therefore the employees can act up all they want and nothing will happen to them, and they know this and take full advantage of it.

I was not the only college graduated hire that felt the same way.
